qas.question: Who ran the Boston School for Deaf Mutes?
What name does the Boston School for Deaf Mutes go by now?

answers.text: the public Horace Mann School for the Deaf

qas.question: What month did Bell go to Boston?
What city was the American Asylum in?

context: Bell's father was invited by <a0_0>Sarah Fuller<a0_0/>, principal of the Boston School for Deaf Mutes (which continues today as <a1_0>the public Horace Mann School for the Deaf<a1_0/>), in Boston, Massachusetts, to introduce the Visible Speech System by providing training for Fuller's <a3_0>instructors<a3_0/>, but he declined the post in favor of his son. Traveling to Boston in <a2_0>April<a2_0/> 1871, Bell proved successful in training the school's instructors. He was subsequently asked to repeat the program at the American Asylum for Deaf-mutes in <a4_0>Hartford<a4_0/>, Connecticut, and the Clarke School for the Deaf in Northampton, Massachusetts.
